children.value: How to slice and dice pandas dataframes and dataseries
How to use pandas for exploratory data analysis
You will often see the nickname
used as an abbreviation for pandas in the import statement, just like
, which allows us to use example datasets created for Pythia.

import pandas as pd
from pythia_datasets import DATASETS
, two-dimensional columnar structure, similar to a table, spreadsheet, or the R
can be lists, dictionaries, NumPy arrays, pandas
, or many other data types not mentioned here. Within these
, you can have data values of many different data types used in Python and NumPy, including text, numbers, and dates/times. The first column of a
, shown in the image above in dark gray, is uniquely referred to as an
; this column contains information characterizing each row of our
can label rows by text, numbers, datetime objects, and many other data types. Datetime objects are a quite popular way to label rows.
For our first example using Pandas DataFrames, we start by reading in some data in comma-separated value (
) format. We retrieve this dataset from the Pythia

class (imported at the top of this page); however, the dataset was originally contained within the NCDC teleconnections database. This dataset contains many types of geoscientific data, including El Nino/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) indices. See
for more information on these indices and the underlying data.
As described above, we are retrieving the datasets for these examples from Project Pythia’s custom library of example data. In order to retrieve datasets from this library, you must use the statement
. This is shown and described in the Imports section at the top of this page. The
class will automatically download the data file specified as a string argument, in this case
, and cache the file locally, assuming the argument corresponds to a valid Pythia example dataset. This is illustrated in the following example.
Once we have a valid path to a data file that Pandas knows how to read, we can open it, as shown in the following example:
, it will render as text by default, in a tabular-style ASCII output, as shown in the following example. However, if you are using a Jupyter notebook, there exists a better way to print
As described above, there is a better way to print Pandas
. If you are using a Jupyter notebook, you can run a code cell containing the
object name, by itself, and it will display a nicely rendered table, as shown below.
index, as described above, contains information characterizing rows; each row has a unique
value, which is displayed in the index column.  By default, the
are represented as sequential integers, which start at 0.
At the moment, the index column of our
is not very helpful for humans. However, Pandas has clever ways to make index columns more human-readable. The next example demonstrates how to use optional keyword arguments to convert
s to a human-friendly datetime format.

Each of our data rows is now helpfully labeled by a datetime-object-like index value; this means that we can now easily identify data values not only by named columns, but also by date labels on rows. This is a sneak preview of the
functionality of Pandas; this functionality enables a large portion of Pandas’ timeseries-related usage. Don’t worry;
will be discussed in full detail later on this page. In the meantime, let’s look at the columns of data read in from the
...is essentially any one of the columns of our
also includes the index column from the source
, in order to provide a label for each value in the
is a fast and capable 1-dimensional array of nearly any data type we could want, and it can behave very similarly to a NumPy
. You can take a look at any of the
, either by using its column name and the Python
notation, or by using dot-shorthand with the column name:

You can also use the dot notation illustrated below to specify a column name, but this syntax is mostly provided for convenience. For the most part, this notation is interchangeable with the dictionary notation; however, if the column name is not a valid Python identifier (e.g., it starts with a number or space), you cannot use dot notation.

children.label: Slicing and Dicing the DataFrame and Series

children.value: In this section, we will expand on topics covered in the previous sections on this page. One of the most important concepts to learn about Pandas is that it allows you to
access anything by its associated label
As a review of previous examples, we’ll start our next example by pulling a
You can use syntax similar to that of NumPy
to index, select, and subset with Pandas
You can also use labels alongside Python dictionary syntax to perform the same operations:
You can probably figure out some ways to extend these indexing methods, as shown in the following examples:
of the final value, following Python’s usual indexing rules.
However, there are many more ways to index a
. The following example shows a powerful and useful indexing method:
This is an example of label-based slicing. With label-based slicing, Pandas will automatically find a range of values based on the labels you specify.
As opposed to index-based slices, label-based slices are
If you already have some knowledge of xarray, you will quite likely know how to create
objects by hand. This can also be used in pandas, as shown below.  If you are completely unfamiliar with xarray, it will be covered on a
In this section, we introduce ways to access data that are preferred by Pandas over the methods listed above. When accessing by label, it is preferred to use the
method, and when accessing by index, the
method is preferred. These methods behave similarly to the notation introduced above, but provide more speed, security, and rigor in your value selection. Using these methods can also help you avoid
These subsetting capabilities can also be used in a full
; however, if you use the same syntax, there are issues, as shown below:
can crash your program. A proper way to subset a
, pandas will not assume as readily the intention of your code. In this case, using a row label by itself will not work;
, labels are used for identifying columns
As shown below, you also cannot subset columns in a
From earlier examples, we know that we can use an index or label with a
to pull out a column as a
, and we know that we can use an index or label with a
to pull out a single value.  Therefore, by chaining brackets, we can pull any individual data value out of the
However, subsetting data using this chained-bracket technique is not preferred by Pandas. As described above, Pandas prefers us to use the
methods for subsetting.  In addition, these methods provide a clearer, more efficient way to extract specific data from a
When using this syntax to pull individual data values from a DataFrame, make sure to list the row first, and then the column.
methods also allow us to pull entire rows out of a
In the next example, we illustrate how you can use slices of rows and lists of columns to create a smaller

df.loc[
    "1982-01-01":"1982-12-01",  # slice of rows
    ["Nino12", "Nino3", "Nino4", "Nino34"],  # list of columns
]
There are certain limitations to these subsetting techniques. For more information on these limitations, as well as a comparison of

children.value: Pandas also gives you a few shortcuts to quickly investigate entire
method shows the first five rows of a
method shows the last five rows of a
A good way to explore your data is by making a simple plot. Pandas contains its own
method; this allows us to plot Pandas series without needing
.  In this example, we plot the

, which generated a single line plot. Line plots can be helpful for understanding some types of data, but there are other types of data that can be better understood with different plot types. For example, if your data values form a distribution, you can better understand them using a histogram plot.
The code for plotting histogram data differs in two ways from the code above for the line plot. First, two series are being used from the
instead of one.  Second, after calling the
method, we call an additional method called
, which converts the plot into a histogram.

The histogram plot helped us better understand our data; there are clear differences in the distributions. To even better understand this type of data, it may also be helpful to create a box plot. This can be done using the same line of code, with one change: we call the

Just like the histogram plot, this box plot indicates a clear difference in the distributions. Using multiple types of plot in this way can be useful for verifying large datasets. The pandas plotting methods are capable of creating many different types of plots. To see how to use the plotting methods to generate each type of plot, please review the

The pandas plotting methods are, in fact, wrappers for similar methods in matplotlib. This means that you can customize pandas plots by including keyword arguments to the plotting methods.  These keyword arguments, for the most part, are equivalent to their matplotlib counterparts.

df.Nino34.plot(
    color='black',
    linewidth=2,
    xlabel='Year',
    ylabel='ENSO34 Index (degC)',
    figsize=(8, 6),
);
Although plotting data can provide a clear visual picture of data values, sometimes a more quantitative look at data is warranted. As elaborated on in the next section, this can be achieved using the
method is called on the entire
, and returns various summarized statistics for each column in the
We can garner statistics for a
method. When this method is called on a
, a set of statistics is returned in tabular format.  The columns match those of the
, and the rows indicate different statistics, such as minimum.
You can also view specific statistics using corresponding methods. In this example, we look at the mean values in the entire
method.  When such methods are called on the entire
is returned. The indices of this
are the column names in the
, and the values are the calculated values (in this case, mean values) for the
If you want a specific statistic for only one column in the
, pull the column out of the
with dot notation, then call the statistic function (in this case, mean) on that column, as shown below:
Slicing is a useful technique for subsetting a
, but there are also other options that can be equally useful. In this section, some of these additional techniques are covered.
uses datetime values for indices, you can select data from only one month using
. In this example, we specify the number 1, which only selects data from January.
This example shows how to create a new column containing the month portion of the datetime index for each data row. The value returned by
is used to obtain the data for this new column:
This next example illustrates how to use the new month column to calculate average monthly values over the other data columns. First, we use the
method to group the other columns by the month.  Second, we take the average (mean) to obtain the monthly averages. Finally, we plot the resulting data as a line plot by simply calling

by the column specified as an argument.
You can also reverse the ordering of the sort by specifying the

In these examples, we illustrate a process known as resampling. Using resampling, you can change the frequency of index data values, reducing so-called ‘noise’ in a data plot. This is especially useful when working with timeseries data; plots can be equally effective with resampled data in these cases. The resampling performed in these examples converts monthly values to yearly averages. This is performed by passing the value ‘1Y’ to the
One of the most commonly used features in Pandas is the performing of calculations to multiple data values in a

simultaneously. Let’s first look at a familiar concept: a function that converts single values.  The following example uses such a function to convert temperature values from degrees Celsius to Kelvin.

def convert_degc_to_kelvin(temperature_degc):
    """
    Converts from degrees celsius to Kelvin
    """

    return temperature_degc + 273.15
The following examples instead illustrate a new concept: using such functions with
. For the first example, we start by creating a
; in order to do so, we subset the
column. This has already been done earlier in this page; we do not need to create this
again. We are using this particular
for a reason: the data values are in degrees Celsius.
Here, we look at a portion of an existing
column. Notice that this column portion is a Pandas
As shown in the following example, each Pandas
contains a representation of its data in numpy format. Therefore, it is possible to convert a Pandas
into a numpy array; this is done using the
This example illustrates how to use the temperature-conversion function defined above on a
object. Just as calling the function with a single value returns a single value, calling the function on a
object. The function performs the temperature conversion on each data value in the
is converted to a numpy array, as described above. The function then converts each value in the numpy array, and returns a new numpy array with all values sorted.
It is recommended to only convert
to NumPy arrays when necessary; doing so removes the label information that enables much of the Pandas core functionality.
As described above, when our temperature-conversion function accepts a
as an argument, it returns a
. We can directly assign this returned
to a new column in our
In this final example, we demonstrate the use of the
file. This example also demonstrates the
Pandas is a very powerful tool for working with tabular (i.e., spreadsheet-style) data
There are multiple ways of subsetting your pandas dataframe or series
Pandas allows you to refer to subsets of data by label, which generally makes code more readable and more robust
Pandas can be helpful for exploratory data analysis, including plotting and basic statistics
One can apply calculations to pandas dataframes and save the output via
In the next notebook, we will look more into using pandas for more in-depth data analysis.
